name: Letter from Lipsius, Justus to Clusius, Carolus, 1593-03-21

Diplomatic.text: I[ustus] Lipsius Car[olo] Clusio S[alutem] D[icit]. Ambigebam an scriberem, mi Clusi, incertus scilicet an etiam esses illic. Videbaris enim ad Batavos inclinare, ut postrema quidem tua scriptio indicabat. Deus quidquid facies, fortunet. E iactatione recepi me Lovanium, Ordinum honesto vocatu. Valetudo mea volebat prorsus sedem firmam. Colimus nunc serio hortos, sed sub initia insigni damno. Nam postremum hoc gelu plures flores mihi abstulit: anemonas omnes, tulipas aliquot, et plerasque omnes afflixit, adeo ut paucas habiturus sim quae florescent. Fuit acre hoc gelu apud nos et cum nive superveniente, quae magis etiam laesit. Texi sane ut potui, sed iniuria caeli vicit vastam curam. Si ita apud vos, non dubito quin tu quoque senseris hanc cladem. Eo minus petere aliquid nunc ausim. Si tamen redundas, memento Lipsii, qui nunc et semper tui. Is, qui has tendet (ita opinor) medicus et mathematicus est Hadrianus Romanus, vocatus ab episcopo Wirceburgensi, quo nunc se confert. Vir doctus est et doctorum cupiens. Vale, mi Clusi. Lovanii, XII. Kal[endas] April[es] M.D.XCIII. [Address:] Clarissimo Viro Carolo Clusio Francofurti. [Clusii manu:] 1593. I[usti] L[ipsi], Lovanii XII K[a]l[endas] Apriles novo calculo ad meas 4 Decembr[is] vet[ere calculo]. Accepi Francofurti pridie Nonas April[es]. Respondi sexto Id[us] eiusdem.

annotations.text: Romanus: Adrianus Romanus, physician and mathematician, was Rector of Leuven university in 1592. In March 1593 he set off to Würzburg, where he had accepted the chair of medicine at the university.

annotations.text: episcopo Wirceburgensi: Julius Echter von Mespelbrunn (Mespelbrunn, 18 Martch1545 - Würzburg, 9 September 1617), scion from a strict Catholic family, studied with the Jesuits in Cologne and at the universities of Leuven, Paris, and Pavia, where he obtained his degree of icenciatus iuris canonici. In 1569 he was appointed to the chapter of the Dom in Würzburg; in May 1575 he was ardained as priest and enthroned as bishop. He immediately devoted himself to restoring the university, with the support of the Jesuits (in 1582). Paladin of the Counterreformation and fervent supporter of the Habsburgs in the war against the Ottomans.

Lovanium: Lipsius had arrived in Leuven on 9 August 1592, after having spent a year in Liège, in anticipation that the States of Brabant approved his appointment at Leuven university. This finally happened in the course of June 1592.
